results.title: Alcheringa
results.brief_description: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian Aborigines.
results.description: Bill Onus hosts this series of films on different aspects of the traditional lifestyle of Australian Aborigines.

results.title: Mutton birds
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Aborigines gather eggs and hunt the mutton bird on small coastal islands. The birds are removed from their burrows, killed and plucked before being loaded onto bark floats to be carried through the surf back to the camp fire.

results.title: Shellfish gathering
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Migratory habits of inland Aborigines who go walkabout to the coast to collect shellfish at certain times of the year, to augment their diet. The husband walks ahead and carries his fire sticks in his hair. His wife goes into the rock pools and quickly fills the string bag which hangs from her shoulder; cooks the fish in their shells in the hot ash; water is poured over the fire to cool the shellfish before they are removed and eaten.

results.title: Walkabout
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
An Aboriginal man and his wife undertake a pilgrimage to the sacred place of the Rainbow Serpent, the controller of rain, water and life on earth. They are shown walking to the coast through an uninhabited land, clambering down cliffs to the ocean. The man carries spears and always walks ahead. Their way of life in tribal times is clearly shown in this brief sequence, as the man carries two spears and walks ahead of his wife.

results.title: Turtle hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Alcheringa”
Shows how Australia’s Aborigines lived hundreds of years ago. Shows unique methods of locating and hunting turtles by wading into shallow pools and feeling for the hard shells with bare feet, grasping their necks by hand, and roasting in hot ashes.

results.title: Hunting a kangaroo
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows Aborigines out hunting for an important source of food, the kangaroo; using boomerang and woomera which are made especially for the purpose. Introduced by Bill Onus and narrated by John Morgan.

results.title: Trading
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Aborigines from central and coastal districts trade their specialities among themselves, in particular weapons of the hunt and of war. Leaving his family at their inland mia-mia, the man travels through dense bush to barter with another Aborigine, so that each may benefit from the other’s skills. They sit face to face and test each weapon for strength before returning with their new possessions. With Bill Onus.

results.title: Woman gathers food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alcheringa”.
To the women falls the task of collecting supplementary foods - such as witchetty grubs and yams. Use is made of a sharply pointed stick to dig under bark for grubs and to kill a lizard which wanders across their path; also to dig for yams. The daughter accompanies her mother on her daily walk and learns the art of food gathering.

results.title: Two laws. Part 2: Welfare times
results.creator_credit: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Part 2 of the docudrama “Two laws”. Describes the life of the Borroloola community under the welfare system of the 1950s to the present day. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alessandro Cavadini, Carolyn Strachan and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Gum preparation, stone flaking etc; (Episode 2)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: In 1965 and in 1967 the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies sponsored a film trip, but eh Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, to the Western Desert Region of Australia. The object of the trip was to film the daily life of nomadic Aborigines of the area. An attempt was made to locate groups still living in the desert. 63,000 feet of film were shot and in this record, or archival version of the material, every shot having ethnographic value is included. Film grammar has, in every case, taken second place. The film is divided into nineteen parts, seventeen of which were purchased for inclusion in the Film Library. Parts 3 and 11 were not purchased as they contain sacred material and , as such, are not suitable for use in schools. The seventeen parts which are in the library are more suited for used in secondary schools than in primary schools. However, titles will be recommended by Curriculum and Research Branch for use with the new Primary Social Studies Course. For general screenings, a condensed version has been made under the title of “Desert People”, catalogue number 2790. 3604. Part 1, 21 min, b&w. Seed-cake making and general camp activity. 3602. part 2, 19 min b&w. Gum preparation, stone flaking, Djagamara leave Badjar.
